Title: October 2020
Content: 32*p64727a03236* *(ii) the diagram shows the life cycle of the tick.autumnthe larvae climb into the vegetation, latching onto any moose that passes by. once attached, they feed for the first time and moult into nymphs. the larvae cannot do this if they are covered in snow.winterafter a few months dormancy on their host, the nymphs feed again and moult into adult ticks.early springfemale ticks, fully engorged on blood, drop off the moose.the ticks die if they fall onto snow.juneafter several weeks dormancy, the females lay their eggs, starting the cycle anew.late winterfeeding begins again as the tick mating season gets under way.late summerwinter tick larvae hatch from clusters of eggs that have been laid on the ground.the ticks feed on the blood of the moose. one tick can remove 200 to 600 times its body mass.the ticks irritate the moose. the moose will scratch against trees causing large clumps of fur to fall off.explain how global warming might affect the life cycle of ticks and result in the decline in the number of moose.use all the information in the question to support your answer.(6)
